name: Teaching Guide: Exploring Immigration and Americanization, 1880-1930

affiliation.name: Wentworth Institute of Technology, Boston, Massachusetts

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. After reading the text discussing the [critique of Chinese and Irish immigration](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/927), the summary of [arguments for and against immigration](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/929), the pamphlet in [defense of immigration](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/930), the [speech delivered by a German immigrant](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/931), and the [pamphlet calling on immigrants to embrace an American identity](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/932), how would you define “Americanization?” 
2. After reading the text discussing the [critique of Chinese and Irish immigration](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/927), the text describing [medical examination of potential immigrants](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/928), the summary of [arguments for and against immigration](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/929), and the [pamphlet calling on immigrants to embrace an American identity](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/932), summarize the arguments that were presented against immigration. Who mounted this opposition?
3. After reading the summary of [arguments for and against immigration](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/929) and the [pamphlet in defense of immigration](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/930), summarize the arguments that were presented in favor of immigration. Who favored immigration and why?
4. Considering the two photographs, the [play](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/926), the [memoir](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/933), and the two postcards, how would you describe the process of immigration? What did individuals and families experience?

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text: Ask groups of three to four students to read over different portions of the play. Have each group discuss and then outline their plan for a contemporary version of such a production. Which immigrant groups would they spotlight? What aspects of their experience would they hope to capture? What broader message would they hope to convey through the production?
